summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel regarding the drafting of a notice to victims about Ghislaine Maxwell's upcoming arraignment and bail hearing. The correspondence shows coordination on the details of the hearing, including its remote format and the government's position seeking detention.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case whose arraignment and bail hearing is scheduled for July 14, 2020. The government expects her to plead not guilty and is seeking her continued detention.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: The judge before whom Ghislaine Maxwell's arraignment and bail hearing is scheduled to take place.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case, specifically the upcoming arraignment and bail hearing.

events.title: Maxwell Arraignment and Bail Hearing
events.description: A scheduled court proceeding for Ghislaine Maxwell to enter a plea and for the court to determine bail. The hearing will be held remotely with a video feed available and an audio dial-in for the public.

locations.address: Clerk's Office, 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY 10007
locations.context: The location of the court where Ghislaine Maxwell's arraignment and bail hearing is scheduled. A live video feed will be available in the Jury Assembly Room at this address.

keyFacts: The U.S. government expected Ghislaine Maxwell to enter a plea of not guilty at her July 14, 2020 arraignment.
The government was formally seeking Maxwell's continued detention pending trial, opposing bail.
The hearing was scheduled to be conducted remotely due to circumstances (likely the COVID-19 pandemic), with provisions for public audio access.
The correspondence shows the U.S. Attorney's Office coordinating victim notification in compliance with the Crime Victims' Rights Act.
The document is a draft notice being revised, indicating procedural communication within the prosecution team.
